note: Combinatorial Number Systems allow for enumeration of ${\binom n k}$. That is, given $n$ symbols from $[0,n)$, generate all lists of length $k$ that represent a sampling from the $n$ symbols. One interesting fact that if $0 \le c_1 < c2 < \cdots < c_{k-1} < c_k < n$ then $ \sum_{j=1}^{k} {\binom {c_j} j} \in [0,{\binom n k} )$. That is, the sum enumerates all possibilities. The proof is by induction on $n+1,k+1$.
